history.content:
If you've had decent data science internships but can't even get chances to interview at mid/top companies that need data scientists, something is wrong. I'd work on improving your resume and your soft skills which can do wonders at in person career fairs. Resume workshops are available on campus or you can anonymously post them on sites like reddit/quora to get outside advice.

Getting to the interview is just as important as passing them.

______________________________________________________________________

As a data science major, I personally don't think pursuing top tier software jobs are worth the time/effort, considering even CS/EECS majors cannot make them deterministically. You should focus on what you're good at and try to advertise the skills you already have, as most SWE full-time positions expect advanced upper division coursework (which you might have not pursued).


Also this craze for a "top company", I'd say is something that you can't do much about. You can give your best shot but its definitely a hit-or-miss so you shouldn't be relying on working at a "top" company (I'm assuming you wanna include all companies that pay well in your definition) for your future career. Remember that you can also switch over to a "top" company once you spend a few years in industry and do great work: not everyone can expect a headstart by starting out at Jane Street or Two Sigma, these firms are extremely difficult to get into anyway, and sometimes, things just don't work out the way you want them to.

Lastly, you should consider applying to grad school as this would open up more of the data science roles for you and give you another chance.

If you've had decent data science internships but can't even get chances to interview at mid/top companies that need data scientists, something is wrong. I'd work on improving your resume and your soft skills which can do wonders at in person career fairs. Resume workshops are available on campus or you can anonymously post them on sites like reddit/quora to get outside advice.

Getting to the interview is just as important as passing them.

______________________________________________________________________

As a data science major, I personally don't think pursuing top tier software jobs are worth the time/effort, considering even CS/EECS majors cannot make them deterministically. You should focus on what you're good at and try to advertise the skills you already have, as most SWE full-time positions expect advanced upper division coursework (which you might have not pursued).
Also this craze for a "top company", I'd say is something that you can't do much about. You can give your best shot but its definitely a hit-or-miss so you shouldn't be relying on working at a "top" company (I'm assuming you wanna include all companies that pay well in your definition) for your future career.

Lastly, you should consider applying to grad school as this would open up more of the data science roles for you and give you another chance.

If you've had decent data science internships but can't even get chances to interview at mid/top companies that need data scientists, something is wrong. I'd work on improving your resume and your soft skills which can do wonders at in person career fairs. Resume workshops are available on campus or you can anonymously post them on sites like reddit/quora to get outside advice.

Getting to the interview is just as important as passing them.

children.subject:
I guess the OP means earning 150-200k right after college. Running after money lol
But nah, it could mean jobs in top companies which are well-known and doing well (kinda fits the above definition too)

history.subject: Feeling kind of lost career wise

history.content:
Senior, majoring in Data Science, previous internship experience at NASA as a Software Developer and also at a decently well known financial services company as a Data Analyst.

1. I can't get top or even mid-tier SWE roles, as I only recently got into practicing data structures and algorithms interview questions, so I'm pretty bad at them. Obviously I'm practicing daily, but yeah that's my current situation. 

2. Can't get interviews for new grad data science / data analyst roles at top companies. I actually feel like I'm qualified for these and meet all the job requirements, but for some reason I'm not getting many interviews. Especially at companies that are Big 4 level, it seems a lot of these positions go to people who are well connected, get referrals, attractive, active in campus orgs and all that other social stuff, etc. Yeah I understand that many data science / analyst jobs require graduate degrees, but it is a little discouraging to not hear back from the jobs that are for bachelor's new grads.

3. My sibling who works on Wall St recommended I look into trading and / or quantitative roles at financial firms. These intrigue me and I think might fit my personality better than the tech / startup scene, but I've only recently started prepping for these interviews, so I would have no chance at a place like Two Sigma, Jane Street, etc. 

Out of the three career paths I mentioned finance interests me the most. I think it fits my personality best. I've seen this forum give some great advice and tough love which is why I decided to post here.
